metadata.title: Abdominal Muscle Strain
anatomical location body part affected: Abdominal wall muscles (rectus abdominis, internal oblique, external oblique, and transverse abdominis), rectus sheath

Abdominal wall muscles function mainly as core stabilizers and trunk mobilizers –The stabilization provided by the abdominal muscles enables the maintenance of trunk and spinal posture, especially during activity against gravity. The most notable stabilizers are the transverse abdominis and internal oblique muscles –The abdominal muscles function as trunk flexors and rotators, and also tilt the pelvis. The rectus femoris is the primary flexor of the spine and compressor of the abdominal and pelvic cavities. The internal and external obliques assist in trunk side flexion and rotation
description: An anterior abdominal wall strain commonly involves the rectus abdominis(1,2,3)
A “side strain” in sports often involves the internal oblique and sometimes the external oblique(1,2,14)

Immediate onset of pain characterizes blunt trauma to the abdominal wall in severe strains, whereas delayed-onset  muscle soreness (DOMS) (see Clinical Review…Delayed-Onset  Muscle Soreness [DOMS] ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708568) is associated with mild and moderate strains
This Clinical Review does not cover diastasis recti or abdominal wall pain in pregnancy

ICD-10 codes.S30.1: abdominal contusion (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The chief complaint is diffuse sharp pain in the abdominal wall, ranging from the costal arch of the rib cage to the iliac crests and pubic arch, that increases on resisted trunk flexion/rotation and stretching of the involved muscles
Signs and symptoms include point tenderness, abdominal guarding/splinting, and reduced function, as well as bruising, swelling, and muscle spasms in severe cases
Pain increases with digital palpation of the tender area and when the involved abdominal muscle is tensed or stretched(3)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: During the acute phase, patients may experience severe pain during transfers or position changes. Attempt to limit the number of times patient has to change positions (e.g., supine to sit, prone to supine)during examination

causes: Indirect trauma is the main cause of abdominal muscle strain that occurs when the abdominal muscles are involved inan unusual forceful activity or movement.(13)For example, forceful trunk side flexion with axial rotation as in throwing(e.g., javelin or discus) or swinging (e.g., tennis, volleyball, ice hockey, golf, baseball) can cause abdominal muscle strain,particularly of the internal oblique(1,2,14)
Forceful eccentric action of the internal oblique was associated with strain of the stretched contralateral external oblique ina soccer player(15)

Blunt trauma from occupational and vehicular accidents, falls, and contact sports (especially martial arts, wrestling, andboxing) is the primary cause of severe gross abdominal muscle fiber/tendon tearing and contusion

Mild-to-moderate  abdominal strains can be caused by unaccustomed repetitive abdominal muscle exertion (as in sit-ups,rowing, or climbing). Such exercise-related  strains often produce DOMS, which is characterized by soreness that worsensduring the first 24 to 48 hours, peaks, and then resolves spontaneously.(3,4) Straining weakened abdominal muscles incompression (e.g., defecation) might also provoke injury
Excessive subcutaneous fat or chronic bloating may overstretch the abdominal wall, leading to muscle weakness and eventearing of the linea alba(3)
pathogenesis: The hallmark of muscle strain is microscopic tearing or pulling apart of myofibers

The author of a cohort study (N = 55 patients with chronic abdominal wall pain) in Germany found that the most commonsites of pain were:(13)–linea semilunaris on either side of the rectus abdominis (71%)–linea alba between xiphoid and umbilicus (13%)–rectus abdominis (9%)–costal margins of the ribs (7%)

Electron microscopy reveals that tearing usually occurs at the Z-lines  of myofibrils in series. The likely mechanism ofthis myofibrillar tearing is overstretching during eccentric (anti-gravity)  work.(4) For example, eccentric stretching of theabdominal muscles opposes gravity during the “down phase” of sit-ups
Pain-restricted  functional mobility in the acute and subacute stages (< 2 weeks) is associated with deficits in abdominalwall flexibility and strength
Authors of a histological study of rabbits in Spain found that collagen fibers are mainly responsible for the passivemechanical strength and stiffness of the abdominal wall(16)
risk factors: Sudden or repetitive eccentric exercise is a risk factor for abdominal strains. In addition, abdominal muscle fatigue andpoor fitness increase risk of injury. The risk of abdominal wall tears might, therefore, be higher at the beginning of acore-strengthening program(1,2)

Obesity, anxiety, and depression may increase the risk for pain in the lineasemilunaris, linea alba, and costal arch of the ribcage, based on a study of patients in a gastroenterology clinic in Germany(3)

Authors in the United States who conducted a descriptive epidemiological study including baseball players from 1991 to2010 found that abdominal muscle strains made up 5% (n = 393) of all injuries and that nearly all (92%) of these wereinternal/external oblique or intercostal strains. Injuries were commonly contralateral to the dominant arm or batting sideand were attributed to rotational forces(5)
Authors of a case study in Argentina found that the one-handed backhand swing in tennis was associated with an internaloblique strain in a professional player (2)
Children may be at greater risk for abdominal strain than adults due to their relatively smaller muscle mass and lower corestrength(6)

overall contraindications precautions: In acute cases of rectus sheath hematoma, medical examination and imaging are necessary to evaluate for intraabdominal injury(7)
Similarly, acute abdominal pain at rest or during treatment not consistent with the patient’s history is a red flag warranting diagnostic imaging(8)

Caution patient to avoid overstretching the abdominal wall until pain resolves. However, resolution of pain during conservative treatment is not a true indicator of complete recovery from muscle injuries because reduced function (ROM, shock attenuation, and peak work force) may persist.(3,4) Consequently, abdominal muscle performance should be reevaluated before discharge and return to sport/work
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: During the acute phase, patients may experience severe pain during transfers or position changes. Attempt to limit the number of times patient has to change positions (e.g., supine to sit, prone to supine)during examination

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Blunt trauma or exertion-related  injury? What work or recreational activities immediately preceded the injury?

course of treatment.medications: Patient may be taking analgesics for pain
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  In severe abdominal wall injuries, laboratory and imaging studies (abdominal ultrasound, CT scan) are indicated to rule out intraabdominal damage(7)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Pain usually is aggravated by resisted trunk flexion/rotation and stretching, daily activities, and palpation. Pain may be related to position, usually not related to eating or bowel function (suggests intraabdominal pathology)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Pain is commonly located in the abdominal wall, from the costal arch of the rib cage to the iliac crests and pubic arch
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Symptoms include point tenderness, sharp pain in the abdominal wall, and muscle spasms in severe cases. Immediate pain onset characterizes traumatic abdominal wall injuries and severe strains, whereas DOMS (see Clinical Review…Delayed-Onset Muscle Soreness [DOMS] , referenced above) is associated with mild and moderate strains
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Inquire if sleep is disturbed due to pain and document number of wakings/night
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Can the patient breathe in and out fully without pain in the costal arch or abdominal wall? Barriers to learning Are there any barriers to learning Yes __ No __ If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any intraabdominal pathology (cancer, obstetric) or prior abdominal injuries?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Obesity, anxiety, and depression are risk factors for abdominal muscle strain. Conditions that cause chronic bloating increase the risk of abdominal muscle strain
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient’s current fitness program, if any, include core strengthening? Contact sports and sports involving throwing or racquets increase the risk for abdominal muscle strain
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Determine if patient’s pain is limiting function
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, whom patient lives with, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Determine height, weight, and BMI. Does the abdominal wall appear distended because of excessive fat accumulation?Evaluate general movements for muscle guarding and compensation for abdominal painAssess movements of the costal arch of rib cage and abdominal wall
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess abdominal muscle strength in trunk flexion, lateral flexion, and rotation (with manual resistance applied to torso in sitting position, when appropriate). Note pain intensity using V AS. How many abdominal crunches (trunk lifted just high enough to clear scapulae from table) can be performed without pain limitation? –Rectus abdominis isolation can be done when asking the patient to lift head and shoulders while supine(13) –Isometric, concentric, eccentric, and plyometric movements may be necessary to isolate the injury site or to determine the mechanism of injury(13)
observation inspection palpation includi: Any abrasion, swelling, bruising, or abdominal distension? Trigger points may be found along lateral margins of the rectus abdominis muscles. Referred pain may occur with stimulation of a trigger point
Identify the point(s) of maximal abdominal wall tenderness. Palpate the costal arch, iliac crest, and pubic arch for pain suggestive of tearing at the tendon-bone  junction
relevant tests and measures.posture: Is trunk posture normal or asymmetrical because of guarding/splinting?
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active trunk ROM in forward flexion, lateral flexion, and rotation; assess for increased pain with passive overpressure at the end range of each movementAssess ability to perform bed mobility and transfers, as pain from abdominal strain can be debilitating(13)

cryotherapy contraindications: Cryotherapy  contraindications -Raynaud’s syndrome -Cryoglobulinemia -Cold urticaria -Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria -Impaired circulation  -Over area of nerve regrowth
cryotherapy precautions: Cryotherapy  precautions -Hypertension -Hypersensitivity to cold -Over an acute wound -Over superficial nerves
other: To prevent re-injury  of an abdominal strain, avoid premature return to activity and ensure that adequate eccentric strengthening has been prescribed(13)
Wrapping or taping the abdomen is not advised as it may interfere with normal breathing

No high-quality  evidence is available for or against the use of low-intensity  ultrasound or other low- or high-voltage currents, neuromuscular stimulation, or thermal modalities in general for abdominal wall strains

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Abdominal wall pain after blunt trauma or exercise-related  strain. Conservative treatment indicated for pain management, contusion care/protection, activity modification, functional restoration, and patient education for injury care/prevention
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out “Side-stitch”  pain during exercise can mimic internal oblique strain but is transient and resolves with rest Myofascial trigger points(13) Cutaneous nerve entrapment(13) Intraabdominal pathology(13) Athletic pubalgia (sports hernia)(13)
prognosis: Generally excellent, with no long-range  complications for abdominal muscle strain reported in the literature

Authors who conducted the study of baseball players mentioned above in Risk Factors  found the re-injury  rate to be relatively high for this group (12.1%) and they noted an upward trend throughout the course of the study (5)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Physiatrist for consultation, as needed Physician for complicated case with prolonged pain and red flags
treatment summary: Evidence is lacking to support a specific treatment protocol. No RCTs investigating the efficacy of physical therapy interventions for this condition were found in the literature
Rehabilitation should include therapeutic exercises for restoring trunk ROM and core (trunk and pelvic) muscle strength, with gradual return to normal recreational and sport activities

Sample treatment protocol(13) –Utilize rest and cryotherapy to control pain and inflammation soon after the injury –Initiate light stretching and isometrics when appropriate –Progress to concentric strengthening –Advance to eccentric and plyometric strengthening –Maintenance training exercises and re-injury  prevention should continue after returning to activity . restoration of rom: Re-assessment  of trunk and pelvic active and passive ROM

maintenance or prevention: Sport-specific  core strengthening is crucial for injury prevention. Warm-up and stretching may help prevent exercise-related muscle injuries(12)
